problem.tex: Does there exist an analytic function $f:\mathbb{D}\to\mathbb{D}$ with $f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{3}{4}$ and $f'\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{2}{3}$?

solution.tex: For any $a\in\mathbb{D}$ recall $\phi_a$ defined as \[\phi_a(z)=\frac{z-a}{1-\overline az}\] is an automorphism of $\mathbb{D}$. Moreover $\phi'(0)=1-|a|^2$ and $\phi'(a)=\frac{1}{1-|a|^2}$. Define $g:\mathbb{D}\to\mathbb{D}$ as \[g=\phi_{\frac{3}{4}}\circ f\circ\phi_{\frac{-1}{2}}.\] Then $|g'(0)|\leq1$ by Schwarz' lemma. That is, \[\left|g'(0)\right|=\left|\phi_{\frac{3}{4}}'\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)\right|\left|f'\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right|\left|\phi_{\frac{-1}{2}}'(0)\right|\] \[=\frac{1}{1-\frac{9}{16}}\left|f'(0)\right|\left(1-\frac{1}{4}\right)=\frac{\frac{3}{4}}{\frac{7}{16}}\left|f'(0)\right|=\frac{12}{7}\left|f'(0)\right|\leq1.\] This means $|f'(0)|\leq\frac{7}{12}<\frac{8}{12}=\frac{2}{3}$. Thus the answer is no.
